body: you can get the user when the response is being generated in your middleware, the user should be on the r.Context() IIRC
Thanks for the advice, but I'm not understanding at what key it would be in the context. Do you have an example?
I've added these helpers: https://github.com/go-openapi/runtime/blob/master/middleware/context.go#L235-L259 so you can get it from a *http.Request

issue.title: Authentication handler is not given request context.
issue.body:
## Problem statement

There is no request context on the generated auth handler, for example using the Swagger spec below you get the following auth handler spec.

```
	// APIKeyAuthAuth registers a function that takes a token and returns a principal
	// it performs authentication based on an api key Authorization provided in the header
	APIKeyAuthAuth func(string) (interface{}, error)

```

However I would prefer getting the request context passed to me. This mean when I am tracing, my request spans can include the authenticating part too.

## Swagger specification

```
---
  swagger: "2.0"
  securityDefinitions:
    ApiKeyAuth:
      type: apiKey
      in: header
      name: Authorization

  paths:
    /example:
      post:
        security:
          - ApiKeyAuth: []
        responses:
          '200':
            description: OK
```

body:
I am having the same problem.
```middleware.SecurityPrincipalFrom()``` just returns nil.

The context does not seem to contain a principal. When printed, the context is just:
```context.Background.WithValue(type *http.contextKey, val <not Stringer>).WithValue(type *http.contextKey, val 127.0.0.1:8080).WithCancel.WithCancel```

For everyone that is still having trouble with this: I found the reason for this probem and a workaround.

The context contains no principal, because the prinicpal is added to the context further down the handler-chain. Also, the way contexts in go work causes values to be removed from the context once the handler that setted the value returns. (= the values are not available in the previous handlers. Even after the handler called ServeHTTP on the next handler in the chain.)

My current workaround is:
The logging handler adds a value containing a string-pointer to the context. The authorization handler (that is further down the handler-chain) sets the value of this pointer to a string containing the user for the current request. The logging-handler can then (after calling ServeHTTP) use the string-pointer (that now points to a username) to include the username in the printed logs.

This is not really a clean solution, and I do not really like it, but for now it works.

issue.title: #1472 SecurityPrincipalFrom() and request reference
issue.body:
This PR attempts to fix issue #1472. The reference seems to be lost
upon the context Authenticate() method is called. From this point on
the security principal becomes unreachable.

The current proposed alternative even though it works, doesn't seem
to be optimal.
